titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James H. Fraser papers, 1898-1999 and undated RL.11790
titlestmt.author: Richard Collier

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-04 15:49:46 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: James Howard Fraser was a librarian, archivist, scholar and author; Director of the Florham-Madison Library at Fairleigh Dickinson University in New Jersey. The James Fraser papers include photographs and slides, articles, correspondence, brochures and pamphlets, magazines, clippings, reprints and other printed material primarily relating to outdoor advertising and graphic art. Subjects covered include activities in support of war efforts (World War I and World War II), anti-billboard and -advertising controversies, outdoor advertising industry promotion, and discussions of advertising as art. Institutions represented include the Advertising Council (and its precursor, War Advertising Council), General Outdoor, Foster & Kleiser, O.J. Gude, Outdoor Advertising Association of America, Poster Advertising Association and Thos. Cusack Co. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: General Files; Printed and Published Materials; Photographs, Slides and Graphic Designs

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James Howard Fraser was a librarian, archivist, scholar and author; Director of the Florham-Madison Library at Fairleigh Dickinson University in New Jersey. Fraser was born in 1934. He received a Doctorate in Library Science from Columbia University (1972) and worked at Fairleigh Dickinsin University from 1970 until his retirement in 2001. Fraser was a specialist in children's literature (editor of the scholarly journal Phaedrus); graphic arts and outdoor advertising (published The American Billboard: 100 Years in 1990). Fraser served as archivist for the Outdoor Advertising Association of America (OAAA) Archives at Fairleigh Dickinson until it was transferred to Duke University beginning in 1996. Fraser died in 2013.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The James H. Fraser papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2015.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], James H. Fraser Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Neil Rogers and Richard Collier, Dec. 2019;
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2015-0119

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials may be found in the following Hartman Center collections:
General Outdoor Advertising Company plan books;
Outdoor Advertising Association of America (OAAA) Archives;
War Effort Mobilization Campaigns poster collection;

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The James Fraser papers include photographs and slides, articles, correspondence, brochures and pamphlets, magazines, clippings, reprints and other printed material primarily relating to outdoor advertising and graphic art. Subjects covered include activities in support of war efforts (World War I and World War II), anti-billboard and -advertising controversies, outdoor advertising industry promotion, and discussions of advertising as art. Institutions represented include the Advertising Council (and its precursor, War Advertising Council), General Outdoor, Foster & Kleiser, O.J. Gude, Outdoor Advertising Association of America, Poster Advertising Association and Thos. Cusack Co. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.
